column2: Estimation and forecasting of volatility using ARIMA, ARFIMA, and neural network based techniques
Hemanth Kumar P., S. Basavaraj Patil
Souvenir of the 2015 IEEE International Advance Computing Conference, IACC 2015
To determine the lowest error combination of volatility proxy and method
Feed forward NN, inputs with lag
All the proxies mentioned: close to close, Garman.klass, Parkinson, Roger, Yang.
S&P500 from March 3rd 2005 to March 3rd 2015. End of day prices, open close high low volumn and adjusted closing price, total of 2517 samples.
Volatility proxy, forecasted 10 days in advance
Parkinson better with ARFIMA, GarmanKlass better with ARIMA and NN. Overall, GarmanKlass and ARIMA had the lowest error
ME, RMSE, MAE, MPE, MAPE, MASE, ACF1

Previously, a simple close to close method was used to proxy volatility. Now, there are so many more methods which have shown lower errors in forecasting, such as Garman.klass, Parkinson, Roger, Yang. However, lower error does not really mean much, a specific proxy could have arbitrarily low error if scaled so.
This paper mentions implied volatility a lot, but it is actually not implied volatility, just future predicted volatility
